Explanations about Options.-i(C): xclip will do what you want .  "xclip -selection clipboard -i <file>".
Explanations about Options.-i(M): read text into X selection from standard input or files (default)
Explanations about Options.-l(M):
number of X selection requests (pastes into X applications) to wait for before
 exiting, with a value of 0 (default) causing xclip to wait for an unlimited number
 of requests until another application (possibly another invocation of xclip) takes
 ownership of the selection
Explanations about Options.-selection(M):
specify which X selection to use, options are "primary" to use XA_PRIMARY
 (default), "secondary" for XA_SECONDARY or "clipboard" for XA_CLIPBOARD
Explanations about Options.-t(M):
specify a particular data format using the given target atom. With -o the special
 target atom name "TARGETS" can be used to get a list of valid target atoms for this
 selection. For more information about target atoms refer to ICCCM section 2.6.2

Answers.MP Summary: command line interface to X selections (clipboard)

Explanations about Options.--attributes-only(C): do "cp -R --attributes-only somedirectory destinationdirectory". From "man cp" .   --attributes-only don't copy the file data, just the attributes.
Explanations about Options.--attributes-only(M): don't copy the file data, just the attributes
Explanations about Options.-r(C): So the exact command you'd want is "cp -r ~/a* .". This should do the trick: .  "cp -r ~/a* <path-to-end-directory>".

Answers.Most Similar TLDR Task: Recursively copy a directory's contents to another location (if the destination exists, the directory is copied inside it)

Explanations about Options.-o(M): write the selection to standard output.

Explanations about Options.-d(M):
Cause files of type directory being copied or archived, or archive members of type
 directory being extracted, to match only the directory file or archive member and
 not the file hierarchy rooted at the directory.
Explanations about Options.-f(M):
Specify archive as the pathname of the input or output archive, overriding the
 default standard input (for list and read) or standard output (for write). A single
 archive may span multiple files and different archive devices. When required, pax
 will prompt for the pathname of the file or device of the next volume in the
 archive.
Explanations about Options.-w(M):
Write files to the standard output in the specified archive format. When no file
 operands are specified, standard input is read for a list of pathnames with one per
 line without any leading or trailing <blanks>.

Answers.MP Summary: read and write file archives and copy directory hierarchies
Answers.Most Similar TLDR Task: List the contents of an archive
